title: dEarring#85: Three kings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here is the second part of the christmas series, this one fits well with the crib-earring ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14171 ).
I almost finished coloring that one, stay tuned for updated pictures. The three crowns I did earlier where not used in this project, as the figures are so tiny, they where not usefull. As you can see the 3d file is low-detail, but as the base size is about as big as a cent coin, I had to simplify it in order I can print it rigid enough. The three kings are bringing gifts to new born child. Of course they also have their Camel with them.
Smoking is not healthy. Let's hope they'll make it. I know the whole three-kings thing is a modern myth, but then, what isn't... This is the third revision, one of the reasons I am late with posting these. The figures are slighlty larger then the previous humans, but the overall size is about the same as the first one of the series.
I tried printing them closer together, but it was impossible to clean without breaking it.

Low support and raft density settings, carefully clean with tweezers...
Color.
I might post more details when I finished the project.

author: stado65

description.text:
I used Sugru around the motor spindle, to close the motor container and around the wires to seal the motor container.
It's working great, it has been one week now that it's working with a phone charger (5V), it's just pumping it's own water and put it back in its aquarium, to test the waterproof capabilities of it.
Instead of Sugru you could use a Hot Glue Gun, it would work too, just make sure there's least bubbles in the glue as possible. You could also put some to glue the base and the casing to have no leaks.

You can use DVD/CD reader/burner motors.

"Protec.stl" : The cover for the motor container.
"Bas.stl" : The base of the pump.
"Housse.stl" : The case of the pump.
"Impeller.stl" : The impeller of the pump, I didn't changed it (see Remix Source File).
"Pompe.x3g" : If you have a Replicator 1 Dual, you can use this to print the pump at the
best settings I found, no need to export and everything in MakerBot Soft.

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

30%

comments.text: My CD/DVD motor, (I have 2), has the shaft connected to the outer body. In other words, the outer body and shaft spin as one piece. How would you get this to work then and still be water proof? The shaft does not come out of the motor, it is part of the assembly.
comments.author: hdstonemeister

comments.text: Well of course the shaft must stay inside the motor, you put the whole motor inside the pump !
comments.author: hdstonemeister

comments.text: I think you misunderstood. On your model, the shaft is separate. On my model, the shaft AND outside housing is one piece. The large body, (circle), spins WITH the shaft. In your workup, it would seem that the shaft needs to spin by itself. Am I wrong, or am I missing something. Thank you for your help.
comments.author: Sceeker

comments.text: Oh ok I just understood. Well unless you can find a way to mount your motor so that the body and shaft can spin freely it might work, but I think that this would be pretty hard to do. But the motor I used only the shaft spins of course.

description.text:
This was a requested model (a 1955 cooling tower that isn't available anymore to be used for a model railroad set) at the 3d printing lab where I work, so I took on the challenge. The base should fit right into the tower itself, and the walkway should slide onto the top.

Would work great for Miniature Wargaming, futuristic RPGs, model railroads, or anything else you can think to use it for!

Beware, the tower itself has some manifold issues. Please check your gcode using Cura or a gcode viewer like gcode.ws to make sure that there are no weird spots. Remixes are welcome.

Enjoy! Please post pictures if you make it!

description.text:
Are you using a webcam with your AXIOM but don't have a way to attach it to the printer? Put that duct tape away and print this simple webcam bracket. No supports needed!

Required Tools and Supplies:
T20 Torx screwdriver
Webcam - We used a Logitech C615: http://amzn.com/B004YW7WCY
[1] 3/4" long 1/4-20 bolt with 7/16" hex head
[1] USB extension - We had to extend the C615 USB cable: http://amzn.com/B00NH11R3I
[2] Small pieces of double-sided tape to attach cables holders to the side of the AXIOM.
[2] Small zip-ties to attach the camera cable to the cable holders.

Assembly Instructions (see numbered pictures above):

  1. The bracket will be installed in the top right corner of the printer.
  2. Remove the factory installed screw that holds front panel to the printer chassis.
  3. Install the bracket socket on the front of the printer using the factor installed screw you removed in the previous step. Most webcams are pretty light, but some may require a bit of double sided tape placed on the back side of the socket to keep it from rotating.
  4. Slide the bracket arm into the socket.
  5. Attach the webcam to the main camera bracket using the bracket knob and 1/4-20 bolt and slide it onto the bracket arm. It is friction mount, but you may want to use some glue to permanently attach the bracket to the arm. Gorilla Glue Gel or some other super glue works great for this.
  6. Use double-sided tape to attached cable holders to the side of the AXIOM and secure the USB cable with zip-ties.
  7. While this front position provides an ideal view of the build area while keeping your camera away from the internal heat, it does block the door. Just slide the entire bracket out of the socket and place it on top of the printer whenever you need access.

The last image shows the camera view you get with this bracket/camera combo. The C615 camera does allow for a little bit of pan and tilt adjustment.

Printer:

Airwolf 3D AXIOM

Yes

No

200 microns

25%

description.text: An ornament for your christmas tree! I was inspired by the tear-drop shaped ornaments and a whisk (May be the perfect gift for the chef in the family!) and experimented with the negative space created inside.

This thing is part of a final project for CPSC 183 Technology and the Law with Prof. Brad Rosen at Yale University. The idea of this project is to ask friends for ideas for physical objects that they would like to have that could be printed on the Makerbot TOM. I have designed them, printed them out and given them to the people who requested them. I also have uploaded them here to Thingiverse to add to the library of physical objects that people find cool, useful, or just plain fun!
Print out and clean support material. May require thin tweezers to remove internal support structure.

author: gvanlandeghem

description.text:
Very much a work in progress, will be updating with a new revision in a couple of weeks, but thought I would upload to see if there was any feedback.

Takes around 70-80 hours to print at 140 micron.

Parts list, build details and maybe code available in the future.

I have built the first prototype with a camera for visual tracking, sonar for near collision detection and a lidar sensor in the head (for fun because I had one from another project). There is an OLED screen in the chest, a speaker in the head and it all runs off a 3800mah lipo for up to 1 hour.

Balance control is run on an Arduino Leonardo with a custom shield interfacing with a BNO055 fusion IMU. A Raspberry Pi 3 provides OpenCV image processing, drives the audio and display, processes sensor data and provides networking and control interface.

For the moment print at your own risk, it will all fit together without issue but I will be releasing new revisions in the near future.

https://youtu.be/Eqjbp00zH0c

comments.text: Thank you very much for putting this up. It looks perfect, I've been looking for a chassis to use for my next project, which just happens to be a self balancing pi3 with opencv stereo imaging!

comments.text: Thanks for the comments,
comments.author: croadfeldt

comments.text: This is awesome, I'm also starting a self-balancing robot project, also marrying an Arduino to a Pi. In my case, I'm using the Pololu A-Star 32U4 Robot Controller, which is an Arduino with motor drivers with built in level shifters, that mounts on a Pi as a hat.
comments.author: markab

comments.text: Looks like a nice board, but in my case doesn't have enough motor outputs for 2 stepper motors.  Do they do a stepper version?

remixed_from.author: Jabberwock
remixed_from.title: Sailing ship for table top games

description.text:
Sailing ship for table top games w/compartments. Modified to allow for removable tops; caveat - I currently can't test print this on my home printer since the pieces won't fit on my print bed; so it's a work in progress. I will do a test print at 85% scale for a boardgame conversion I'm thinking about; either way, it should work fine, no issues cropped up during netfabb pro scans...

There are some areas in the original model design (windows on stern side) that had some odd angles cut into them so they didn't splice as well as I'd like so there are some odd angles/bits that need to be refined - I'm good with the progress so far and added some internal structure to allow for support of the upper floor. I may end up going back in and splicing out the windows and doors as separate elements at a later time... the middle section has the top as a whole piece and as two separate halves, I believe the mast should slot in fine on the lower deck but it may need extending on the lower portion so you can still remove one half or both halves and still have the mast inserted - hope that made sense.

I think the original design stated that it was created in SolidWorks but I didn't see a source file to work with so I modified this using Fusion360 and Meshmixer as well as import/export testing for model file size/structure using Meshlab/netfabb Pro/Tinkercad - in my past experiences with testing models, oddly enough, if Tinkercad can import a file and it export it without degradation or loss in polygon/faces in the model structure it will usually print/slice on any machine without much fuss, not bad for that little program.

description.text:
[UPD] Don't use this design for delta mechanics.

Even though these clamps are quite strong, their feelers ends seems to be too weak and allow tiny movements of balls along the clamps. Being assembled, whole mechanics is not tough enough, it's getting worse when parts move.

I still like the idea to make compact mechanics, so I will try to redesign clamps to get rid of this soft backlash behavior.

Here is another version of delta mechanics using 16mm ball joints.
It's compact but more strong and solid than previous.

Again, it's compatible with Rostock (platform offset - 33 mm; carriage offset - 22 mm).

Carriages designed to be used with lm8uu bearings.

Note that platform's top and bottom sides different.

Parts' sources are published on Onshape

I've upgraded my printer with the parts made of PLA and currently testing it. Preliminary results are quite promising.

description.text:
6/19/2016: I can't believe I forgot a port for the power plug. Thanks to Tonelock for pointing it out. So...I added a hole, and also trimmed the retaining clips because I found it very trying to remove the 3DS from the grip. Should be less reason to do so now, but still.

This is a remix of zeroordie881's New 3DS XL grip (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1269106). A beautifully done model, but it was just too big when I printed it in PLA (possibly due to the ABS vs PLA shrinkage, or maybe it's just me.)

At any rate, as I needed to resize it, I just went ahead and customized it to my tastes, adding the game cart slot, changing the size and positions of some of the ports, etc. I also added retaining clip/ridges so the 3DS would be more or less secure.

It's not as pretty as I'd prefer because it needed extensive cleanup from the supports (I printed with the bulbous handles down like the original) and probably because of the inferior Hatchbox filament I was using just because I already had it. If I was going to do another I'd probably try printing it in "in use" orientation and see how that goes with the support just on the bottom.

Seemed to my paranoid mind (after 45 hours printing) like something might snap when inserting the game unit, but it all worked great (I slid it in from the back until it snapped into place.) Now all I have to do is buff it, or probably not.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

You could undoubtedly use a much more sparse infill, I just went for a compromise between strength and filament use that pleased me. I do like the silkiness of the fine resolution, though.

description.text:
Replace the metal cover with 3 printed parts and you will be able to observe the process.

  1. Remove the extruder, and unplug hotend and thermistor.
  2. Guide the hotend wiring to the right side.
  3. Mount the parts and reconnect the cable (make sure there is no stress on the cables).

The Ubis-FanHolder is a derivat of https://www.youmagine.com/designs/ubis-metal-hot-end-fan-shroud

BOM:
2 pcs M3 by 6mm screws for mounting the FanHolder to the extruder base.
4 pcs M3 by 16 screws for fixing fan and Mini-Shroud to the FanHolder.

comments.author: Keibatsu

comments.text: I made one.  The problem was neither fan is cooling the heat break, which causes all sorts of jamming (cold end clog) for me.  Once i returned airflow to the heat break everything got better. i dumped the ubis fan holder and added a little bracket attached to the remaining fan holder, so that air flows on the lower portion of the heatsink and the heat break.   Otherwise I like the design, simple and small.
comments.author: hyperionsea

comments.text: Could you add a picture of your setup?
comments.author: hyperionsea

comments.text: Wouldn't the upper fan be cooling the Heat break?
comments.author: hyperionsea

comments.text: No it just hangs on the heat sink fins, and all air is directed through the fins. There is little to no air flow over any other part of the hot end, not that I am sure how much that matters.  But I assume there was a reason for original mounting of the fans, allowing airflow over much of the hot end.  I had a UBIS 13, which has an exposed heat break just below heat sink, while the 13S has the PEEK insulator instead.  However my UBIS 13 was pretty compromised after repeated disassembly for several clog removals.

comments.text: I can place my stl file, place my jpg file and make any adjustments. It just won't let me download the resulting file. In Chrome it says Failed - No file. IE doesn't even give an option to save a file when the Save Model button is pushed.
comments.author: rlenhart2

comments.text: I'm afraid there is a 400/500Mb download limit in the browsers, I've added a compression module that reduces the download size and that will be in the next version, Chrome and FireFox are the best for this, but there is still a limit which the compression solves. It means we'll be able to generate really huge models if needed.  The size is caused to some degree by the number of faces on the surface of the model.  I'm currently increasing those all over the model which is unnecessary and I will limit this to only happen in the areas of the model that have changed.  The compression bit is working, I'll try and upload it over the next few days, I'll also add a field where you can put your email address so that people can be notified of changes if they want to be.

author: 3dlyx

description.text:
I've split the pen arm from thing:844167 into two parts that are attached together with magnets. You should print magnetic_pen_arm_top_part2.stl once, and magnetic_pen_arm_top_part1.stl as many times as you have pens, then you can switch between pens easily and quickly. (You'll obviously need a pair of magnets for each piece that you print too.)

The magnet dimensions and other settings are parametric, check the OpenSCAD file for details. I used 8x1 mm neodymium magnets, you can find them on Aliexpress for instance.

pen_arm_top.stl is the original file by jsc, magnetic_pen_arm_top_part1.stl and magnetic_pen_arm_top_part2.stl are the ones I printed.

Action video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wXIDBlRRZM4

comments.text: This looks interesting.  How well has bit been working out?  Does the pen shift at all when it comes into contact with the egg/sphere?  Do you happen to have any videos showing the arm in action?
comments.author: wombat991

comments.text: It works really well. There is no difference compared to using the original version, except that it's much easier to print designs with several colors. You can name the layers in Inkscape according to the pen you intend to use...
comments.author: wombat991

comments.text: Thanks.  That's good to hear.  I've been struggling with a couple issues regarding multi-color prints on my Sphere-bot, the main one being getting each pen to be at the proper height.  What I did was make a fat "washer" (out of four layers of unused/old raft material that I sealed together with acetone, then drilled a hole in the center of the washer) such that the washer acted like a spacer between the pen arm and the part of the pen body where the end of the cap hits and stops (yeah, I'm doing a bad job of explaining this).  This way I would pop the cap off of the pen, slide the washer on as far as it would go, then put the pen into the pen-arm as far as the pen would go.  This worked well, but I like your design much better.

Regular Mouth Mason Jar chicken feeder!

UPDATE 2011-12-13 07:23
Kylie Karshellian adopted a print of this shell today! See it happen here with annotations and music: http://youtu.be/LtvlLBQnEc0
UPDATE 2011-12-07 21:35
Kendall Karshellian adopted a print of this shell today! See it happen here: http://youtu.be/QpCusZ_q0ww
UPDATE 2011-12-04 19:11
The original oxystele.stl had spiral holes in it. After running it through http://cloud.netfabb.com the holes are gone. If you downloaded the file before, please re-download it.
Another one of M. B. Cortie's greatest hits http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/009784939390054D!
Modeled on the shell of the Oxystele sinensis sea snail, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxystele_sinensis, will Coenobita clypeatus - "Purple Pincher" - hermit crabs like this? Only experimentation will tell!
It was created using Maya's shellNode plugin, which is based upon Cortie's model, and thickened using Blender's Solidify modifier http://www.blender.org/development/release-logs/blender-256-beta/solidify-modifier/.
The goal is a workflow using open source tools, but this shell surface required a commercial tool. Thanks to a tip from http://www.thingiverse.com/mesheldrake, the conversion to a solid is now handled by an open source tool. :)
Cortie's model and many of its resultant shells have been written in Maple http://www.maplesoft.com/applications/view.aspx?SID=3851&view=html. Porting them to an open source tool such as Sage or Blender is the last step in creating a complete open source workflow.
Any python ninjas up to the taskÃÂ¢Ã¢ÂÂ¬ÃÂ½
Follow Project Shellter progress here:
http://projectshellter.com
http://twitter.com/ProjectShellter
http://bit.ly/ProjectShellter
http://bit.ly/ProjectShellterCams
http://bit.ly/ProjectShellterVideos

Some notes:
  • You must use support material, and it's not as difficult as it sounds! Matt's excellent support settings work great: makerbot.com/blog/2011/06/27/makerbot-microtip-using-the-support-features-in-skeinforges-raft-tool/
    For convenience, they are available here for Skeinforge 35: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/39152244/SF35-Thingomatic-HBP-Mk7-MG-Support.zip
  • For printing, you only need the oxystele.stl file; the other file is just a surface and is provided for thickening experiments
  • Printing with the aperture facing up and the shell parallel to the printing surface yields the best quality hollow print so far
  • Once printed, the minimal support material is easily removed and the entire shell is hollow
  • Sanding or tumbling to smooth the surfaces is optional but recommended
    You can print it, I know you can!
    Go!

The Adjustable Bed System allows for the four corners to be independently adjusted for a more accurate first layer. It is designed for 8mm smooth rods, 3/8" wood dowels, heater that is 142mm deep and a glass that is 150mm deep. The nice thing is that it can be for any width.

To make the system you will need:
3/8" wooden dowel rod
4- 8-32 x 1" bolts
4- 8-32 nuts
6- 4-40 x 1/2" bolts
Zip ties Printed parts:
4- bedcorner-dowel
2- BedCenterBeltHolder
4- BedSupport
4- DowelTOffset
4- AdjustKnob
6- GlassClamp
2- GlassHeaterBed Assemble:
Tap the BedSupport with a 8-32 thread. Insert the 8-32 x 1" bolt from the bottom. It should bottom out and not interfere with the dowel.
Tap the 6 GlassHeaterBed holes with a 4-40 thread. Insert the 1/2" 4-40 bold into each of the GlassClamps and screw them into the holes. Orient the GlassClamp for the best fit for you setup.
Attach the bedcorner-dowel parts onto each end of the 8mm rods. Note that the bedcorner-dowel is thicker on one side than the other. This is on purpose to add a couple of mm's to help with clearance.
Measure the wooden dowel across the front and rear and insert the cut lengths.
Place the DowelTOffset on the front and rear dowels and measure for the left and right bed support dowels. Insert the dowels into the DowelTOffset and place on the front and rear dowels. Be sure to adjust the lengths so that they rest precisely on the front and rear dowels.
Insert an 8-32 nut into each of the AdjustKnob.
Assemble the BedSupport, AdjustKnob, GlassHeaterBed and remaining 8-32 nuts and place each assembly on left and right dowels.
Use zip ties to secure it all down. To adjust the bed, turn the AdjustKnobs then secure the position using the BedAdjustTool.

This is the same Dragonboard 410c design as giantpune, but I made the screw holes bigger to fit Home Depot's #4-4 x 3/8" screws and nuts. It's still a pretty tight fit and I had to file a small amount from the bottom of the top cover posts to close nicely. In addition to the adjustments for the screw holes I also made the USB port holes the same size and adjusted the position of a few openings very slightly to reduce covering the connectors. The connector overlap could have just been my printer doing that, but who knows.

title: Bearing block for 8 mm shaft, 3 x 623zz bearings at 120 degrees
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 19.04.2017:
I'm glad to announce VERSION 2 (RED PICTURES).
Improvements:
1/ The back side of bearing block is a tiny bit smaller. Now it does not touch the Prusa frame when the carriage is lifted up to the very top. From now your printing height limit depends not on the carriage but on the nut on the leading screw.
2/ There are several sizes to avoid play. The key to avoid play is the distance from the center of the X-rod to the center of the bearing. Ideally is is 9.00 mm. Other versions are more tight. There are versions:
X_bearing_block_v2_9_00_mm_left = distance is 9.00 mm
X_bearing_block_v2_8_95_mm_left = distance is 8.95 mm
X_bearing_block_v2_8_90_mm_left = distance is 8.90 mm
X_bearing_block_v2_8_80_mm_left = distance is 8.80 mm
X_bearing_block_v2_8_50_mm_left = distance is 8.50 mm
In my case version with 8.95 mm is best. In most cases one of the first three should be OK.
3/ You may mount it one bearing up and two down or two up and one down. They will function equally well.
4/ I have finally (after 18 months working with looong breaks) finished the compact Sunhokey X-carriage for chinese E3D V5 clone. It is just fantastic. Here it is:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2259774

INITIAL DESCRIPTION (YELLOW PICTURES):
The big problem to solve: shaking X-carriage. Here is video of the problem:
http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/sunhokey-3d-printer-owners/topic:5107
The small problem to solve: make X-carriage run faster and smoother with less resistance.

First idea to use 623zz bearings came from tahustvedt:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1149490
But he reports that the bearing block develops play (luft). I suggested it's because of "non-ring" design. But the "full ring" or "full square" design does not fit: it touches belts.

So, the second idea came from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724999
Putting bearing at the 120 deg angle saves some space and allows "full-circle design".

As a result I propose a bearing block with three 623zz bearings (outer diameter 10 mm, inner diameter 3 mm, width 4 mm), which are very cheap. You will need three M3x16 screws. The whole thing does not touch belts. You can mount it to the vertical X-carriage wall with the stock M4 screws.

Location for mounting: you may use two blocks instead of one LM8UU. To make it more stable orient blocks with the bearings looking outside. Wider you place the blocks more stable will be your carriage. At first you may attach it using stock holes for M4 screws. When you will create your own X-carriage you may place the blocks as wide as you like. If they are wide enough on upper shaft you may place only one on the lower shaft.

IMPORTANT: Installation is very simple: you only need to unscrew one M3 screw on the left side of your printer. Than removing one plastic part you will be able to pull out half of the shaft. Than you remove LM8UU from it and put the block on the shaft.
The sequence of pictures shows how to install them.

P.S. This is my first CAD experience. I'm open to critics and improvements.
P.P.S. Here is similar design for Y-axis (table).
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1438544

title: Geeetech Aluminum Prusa I3 Anti-Wobble Bracket

description.text:
This is a set Anti-Wobble Brackets. Their purpose is to isolate the wobble of the threaded Z Axis Rods to improve the print quality. They are designed to replace the factory nuts on the Geeetech Aluminum Prusa I3 that came with stamped steel Z Brackets.

2 standard M8 Nuts available at most Hardware Stores are required. It should be sized correctly, but if the brackets are tight on the smooth Z Rods, some shaving or sanding will be required to allow smooth movement so they will not jam causing lost steps.

Supports are recommended for the area where the nut fits.

Please check out my video: https://youtu.be/mYswkbC_AX0

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lhubjMRleuR

comments.text: This looks like a great mod. I'm fixing to print these out and give them a try. A tip i can share for fixing the captive nut wont fit into the printed piece is to use a cigarette lighter and heat the metal nut to "finger burning temp" and press it into the plastic... it will melt the plastic instead of  cracking it and the nut will fit tight and you won't need to print another.

Update 4/14/2016:
My mpcnc is not yet finalized, but I've gotten it up and running and the mount so far has worked well. I've tried two small carbide burrs (1/8" and 0.1" diameters) on various thicknesses of MDF and plywood (1/4" or less).

estlcam settings were taken from this guide on the mpcnc site.

I intend to find and modify one of the existing vacuum shoe mounts for other tools to clamp to the rotozip so this may not be the final mount I go with. I'm pleased with it so far though.

This is an as yet untested RotoZip RZ20 mount for the Mostly Printed CNC by AllTed. It is designed to fit the Universal Mount by HicWic.

It is a combination of this RotoZip Mount by cor5151 and the Maxi Mount from HicWic's set.

It's designed to be printed separately and snap together (I added a bit of superglue to the keyhole).

I printed mine at 70% infill with PLA. I also used "Support Type: Touching Build Plate" in Cura for the inner top clamp part.

I will add pictures once I've tested it a bit more, as I'm still calibrating and preparing my MPCNC.

The Ricon de la Vieja is an active "andesitic complex volcano" in Costa Rica. The vertical scale is 1.2X. It was constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 0.8 million facets). This software was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

description.text:
Designed to fit straight on to the Ormerod 1 X-carriage (YMMV with Ormerod 2, I don't have one to test it on). Just remove the hot end and the old nozzle mount and bolt the new piece on, then clamp your E3D in place. There is a version with an attachment to mount dc42's hot end board if you wish.

Minimal support material required for a couple of the overhangs, more so if you're printing the dc42 version. You'll want to drill the holes out to 3mm. I used two M3x8 cap heads for the x-carriage and two M3x20 cap heads with two M3 nuts for the clamp.

I'm using it with this duct: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:839620

description.text: If you have old clumsy hands as I have you will love these tools. These are simple, just put a nut on the bench top and press the holder onto the nut to hold it. Then you can position the nut to the bolt in places your fingers can't fit.

Printer:

LymanBot 3D Printer V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I use .5 nozzle, speed slow, infill 30%.

From the pictures, shown are 3mm and 4mm lock nuts fit on the holders. Heat 4mm nut for 10 seconds and push it into the holder. Heat the 3mm nut for 8 seconds and push it into the holder. Use the cold nuts for working the shape so the nuts will fit snugly. So there are 4 holders, two flat ones for 3 & 4mm nuts and two combo for 4 & 3mm nuts one short and one long at 90 degrees from the flat ones. With the combo 3 & 4mm holders you can turn the nut onto the bolt, the flat ones you need to be able to turn the bolt to attach.
I have tried the Finger Nut Holder without success, but these work great.
These are designed with AutoCad 3D modeling.

comments.text: Just finished building my first - of many 3D printers - and about to build a laser engraver - this WILL come in handy - Thank you for sharing!!
comments.author: KD3

comments.text: Just sort of "thinking out loud"...  although 3 & 4 mm will cover most nuts on the east side of "The Pond", they are someyhing of a rarity on the west side.  Seems to me that these might be a good candidate for a "customizer" for SAE (both numbered and inch) and other metric sizes...
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: Thanks for your comment.  In my opinion metric is a better measuring system. As most of the motors and fittings for 3D printers and other such machines are metric I have totally switched from SAE to metric in my designs and fittings.  The tools shown are very simple to design so if you wish SAE just design them. I use both tools for starting nuts on my filament extruder and other inventions.

This is my customized Customizable Android Guy with Text by vorpal, featuring my twitter handle @EvrydyPineapple. I tweaked a few of the parameters in openSCAD:

  • Made the neck a little bigger so his mouth stays open better.
  • Now all the parts snap together firmly without glue.

I made this a customizer so other people can make one too if they want.

This custom upgrade for your boring USB stick is Simple to print and assemble in less than 1h30m

  • Additional parts not printable include:

  • USB Electronics
  • Crazy Glue
  • 2 pen springs
  • Fabric (Customizable)

*Instructions:

  • scale and print plastic components
  • clip in electronic component (i used a"Kingston datatraveler 3G" )
  • glue inner 2 pieces together
  • inset springs at back
  • line up outer pieces but do not glue them together
  • wrap fabric in notch around outside of USB
  • with small brush cover the fabric in a layer of glue (be very careful not to glue any moving pieces)

*Trouble shooting:
-if the USB dose not slide use nail polish remover and oil to clear and bits of leftover glue and lubricate the track

title: Turtle Beach Z300 Headset clip and mount for IKEA desk

description.text:
UPDATE: My initial design for the IKEA desk clip failed. I guess I overestimated the strength of PLA. Anyway, I adjusted the design to be stronger, easier to print and works great now.

I have a Turtle Beach Z300 wireless headset. It works great, but I got tired of it getting stomped or misplaced, so I made a mount that clips onto my IKEA desk. My desk is similar to a jerker, but it has slots instead of holes. I will upload some pics later. This mount SNAPS perfectly onto the desk and provides a hook that is wide enough to hang my headphones.

Speaking of headphones, I should have made this mount sooner because my Z300 broke near the earpiece. Before I bought it, I saw people complaining online that the design was poor and weak in that area. I scoffed and thought it looked strong enough, well, I was wrong. I make a clip that snaps onto the headphone in the weak area and has a tab that extends downward. Once you snap this clip in place, you can wrap it with some black PVC /electrical tape and your headphones will be good as new!
Blender + dial caliper

comments.text: Was lucky to find this - the clip is more useful to me than the desk mount. It's not necessarily obvious just what that clip is for, but I know a lot of people who probably wouldn't object to using it!
comments.author: wild_quinine

comments.text: Thanks, yeah it is basically a splint. I wrapped some electrical tape around it and it has held up fine so far. Was thinking to perhaps put some gorilla glue epoxy or something in the crack area and fill in the splint, but I tried the tape first and it has held up well.

author: donald_stouffer

description.text:
I first tried to model metaballs in OpenScad.  That effort was preliminary, indicating to me that it's not an easy egg to crack.
This thing cracks the proverbial metaball egg.
I have implemented a metaball routine in Banate CAD which gives you fairly decent results in relative real-time.  That is, you can setup a fairly simple network of 'balls', and generate an isosurface for them in a matter of about a second, or a few seconds if you want to go for much higher resolution, or have a network with a ton of balls in it.
Metaballs/Blobs are used quite a lot in games for getting that nice blobbly affect on characters.  It tends to make things look more organic than what you can typically achieve with more mechanical mechanisms.
This is great for modeling as you can quickly try out various configurations of balls to get all sorts of blobby effects.  The "seat", or "face" model included here consists of just 4 influencing balls, so it's fairly simple.
In the picture, I've used fairly high resolution.  The model is much lower resolution, but realistically, it would print about the same.
Also, in the picture, I'm showing the influencing balls, just for visualilzation.  I turn them off to actually generate the .stl file.
I think the approach I'm taking is actually unique, as I haven't quite seen it done my particular way in the literature.  Not a bad result for NOT using the GPU, and doing it purely in Lua.
You can play with the .fab, but it won't have the same results as I'm getting until this Sundays (12/4/2011) release of Banate CAD.

1) Download
2) Print
3) Rejoice

comments.text: this is cool... i am wondering about how you implement it. ..... is it a massive union of hexahedrons?

title: FDL-1 Prototype

description.text:
Update

This thing is more or less deprecated. There is a new version here: thing:1651854

Please visit FDL1.com for more info. I have a webshop there selling assembled blasters, kits and electronics bundles to pair with your printed shell.

The FDL-1 is a robotic foam dart launcher. It is high powered, fully automatic, web enabled, and can be converted between blaster and turret forms. It shoots Nerf Mega size or compatible darts.

This is the prototype version as seen in the FDL-1 Kickstarter. I plan on redesigning a good portion of the FDL-1 in the coming months to box in electronics and round a few edges but there was a lot of interest in the prototype design. Here it is:) The major electronics will stay the same between versions. I will post the improved design separately when it's ready.

I'm working on a more complete list of electronics and hardware, assembly instructions, source code, videos, etc. Everything you'll need to get up and firing. A full FDL-1 print including a handle and turret can take up to a week on a single printer depending on your print settings. I wanted everyone to at least be able to get that process started.

I'm also working on getting a web shop setup to sell the FDL-1 as 3D printed kits, fully assembled, or just the electronics and hardware so all you have to do is print and assemble. Other designs and accessories to come...


Here's a link to the Kickstarter


Just the Kickstarter Video


Some Dad vs Son Basement Stadium Action


And a video review by Drac from the LordDraconical Nerf modding YouTube channel

Assembly Series

Teardown and Overview

Revised Blaster Assembly Part 1


Social Media

Like the FDL-1 on Facebook for updates on the revised design


Visit the FDL-1 website for other links and mailing list signup

Happy printing!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

There are a few parts that need support but I have built it into the models. You shouldn't need to turn it on at all. A mm or two brim might not hurt on parts without a lot of surface area on the printer bed.



The entire model was designed with a 0.4mm nozzle in mind. I'm not sure what effect a different size would make. Darts may fit a little tighter or looser in the revolver. The same goes for screws fitting through holes and into threads.



My current printer has a 6" cube max print size. Some of the parts push each of these dimensions so that is the minimum you'll need without slicing parts into smaller pieces.



I haven't tried printing the FDL-1 in ABS yet. I will soon. PLA works well because it is more rigid. I always use a heated bed, even for PLA. BuildTak is pretty nice too.



Please note, I've gotten feedback that the revolver will not print on a Lulzbot Taz 5. I haven't had issues printing it on my Prinrbot Simple Metal though so I'm not sure if it is a model issue or something more specific to certain printers. If you are attempting to print your own FDL-1, print the revolver first because of this and also because it will take no less than 11 hours to print. If you have issues please send me a message so I can work them out before the next version.

I will get a more complete list up ASAP, but here are the major components you'll need to get started:


Nema 17 Stepper Motor 2A 45Ncm(64oz.in) 17HS16-2004S (2 +2 for turret)


Stepper Motor Driver Pololu DRV8825 (2 +2 for turret)


Brushless Motor Multistar Elite 2204-2300KV (2)


ESC Hobbypower SimonK 30A BEC 2A (2)


Particle Photon wHeaders


Micro Switch Digikey P10864S-ND (2)


SparkFun Solder-able Breadboard - Mini (2 +1 for turret)
Or

Breadboard - Mini Modular (2 +1 for turret)

10k Ohm potentiometer for speed knob
1k Ohm 1/4watt resistor for stepper driver board

A bunch of:
6-32 x 3/8" machine screw
6-32 x 1/2" machine screw

M3x8 hex head screw (16 +8 for turret)
10-32 set screw (2 +6 for turret)
24ish gauge wire for sensor connections, I took apart cat6 cables
16 gauge and 20 gauge silicone stranded wire for battery/power connections
3.5mm bullet connectors for ESC and motor connections

1/8" & 3/16" heat shrink - black, red, white

Again, working on a more complete list...

Philips Screwdriver #2
6-32 tap
10-32 tap
1.5mm allen key
2.5mm allen key
3/32" allen key
Soldering Iron
Wire Clippers
Wire Strippers
Heat Shrink

The source code for the Photon is up on GitHub. I don't claim this to be my best code ever. It is as much a prototype as the rest of the design. Let me know if you have questions or issues with it. I'll add comments and tweaks as needed.


FDL-1p Source Code On GitHub

comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: I don't recall having fit issues with those parts but it's been at least a year since I printed the turret portion of this. You may need to do some sanding to get things to fit the way you want. They shouldn't be far off. I will say you probably want to print the bolt and nut at as fine a resolution as you can so the threads come out clean. It's crucial that they don't curl up as you print. You may have to work the threads a little too or sand them to fit.

comments.text: I've always used 1k because I have a bunch laying around but a higher resistance may be better. I'm good at figuring out what plugs in where, not so good at resistor and cap sizes.
comments.author: Webzter30

comments.text:
What is the resistor between enable and sleep pins on the stepper drivers for?
Thanks
comments.author: Webzter30

comments.text: That's a pull-up resistor between 3.3v and the enable pin. It pulls the enable pin high by default which disables the driver. When pulled low by the photon, there is a more direct flow to ground than through the resistor and the driver is enabled. If this wasn't there, the steppers would be enabled when booting up the blaster until the code is reached that disables them.
comments.author: Webzter30

comments.text: How long are the 10 32 set screws supposed to be?
comments.author: Webzter30

comments.text: 1/4" You could get away with 3/8" if that's easier to find. If you're in the US, you can get all the 6-32 machine screws and set screws at your local big box. You can experiment with using #6 wood screws instead of machine screws to avoid having to tap each hole too. I always tap and use machine screws but it's a prototype design. It's meant to be messed with.

Only a few hitches so far with the test fitting, and then it comes down to waiting for my parts to get here! comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: Awesome! Yeah, that revolver is a beast. It was a 24hr+ print when I first designed it. I simplified the bracing inside and it usually takes around 12-13hrs at a 0.3 layer height on my Printrbot. I will start working on videos and whatnot tonight. I'll do a teardown while explaining all the general workings, then a assembly, then I can get into electronics hookups and the code. I apologize if you progress faster than I get videos up. I've been laser focused on the redesign.
comments.author: fetchbeer

comments.text: You said you're working on a redesign - which components are expected to change?
comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: Most if not all of the printed pieces will change. A lot will remain compatible between the two designs but not all. The electronics will stay the same but some will get repurposed and added. I moved the advance switch under the revolver and added an IR sensor there as well to sense loaded chambers.  There will be a number of mode switches/buttons added. The turret will require an additional photon to open up functionality on both itself and the blaster. I also would like to design custom pcbs to make hooking up the electronics easy. The idea is to get all the wires hidden and make the whole thing easy to assemble. The prototype really takes some electronics know-how to get working. The redesign will be much more plug n play.
comments.author: ChristopherB

comments.text: Ah. good to hear. I'll hold off printing till the redesign launches.
comments.author: JesseKovarovics

comments.text: Thanks!

The Turrialba and Irazu Volcanoes in Costa Rica. The vertical scale is 1.5X. It was constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.8 million facets). This software was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.
The surface described in cylindrical coordinates by z = e^{-kr}*cos(r) is rendered here in a smooth version, two different 2d Riemann sums and a model showing the contours/level curves.

author: lkautz

title: Recycled Bottle Coat Hanger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This hanger was requested by a friend who is very environmentally conscious. I thought this was a great way to recycle 2 bottles while utilizing the TOM's capabilities! A design similar to this by Chinese designer Xuan Yu inspired this thing's creation. 
One thing to note is that the holes to accept the threads to the bottles are not threaded. A compression fit seems to work well enough.

This thing is part of a final project for CPSC 183 Technology and the Law with Prof. Brad Rosen at Yale University. The idea of this project is to ask friends for ideas for physical objects that they would like to have that could be printed on the Makerbot TOM. I have designed them, printed them out and given them to the people who requested them. I also have uploaded them here to Thingiverse to add to the library of physical objects that people find cool, useful, or just plain fun!

Print and clean. I needed to use a Dremel tool to cut the threads off of the bottles I was using and a compression fit worked great! Just make sure the fit isn't too tight or else you might crack the part depending on how it was printed. A dab of superglue on each side and this hanger is all ready.
If you would rather try to screw your bottles in, I would scale it up a few percent (3-5). Don't scale too much though or you won't anything to grab the inner surface. Of course, unless you would rather just push the bottle top right into the socket.

comments.text: Love the idea, this would definitely be easier on jacket shoulders than a metal hanger, and use less plastic than the wide suit hangers (reusing the bulk of the material as PVC)
comments.author: awdemuth

comments.text: you said you used makerbot to print this!?
comments.author: eranglr

comments.text: Sure did with an MK6! I have made some tweaks to my skeinforge preferences, but no extensive hardware upgrades.
comments.author: eranglr

comments.text: This is genius !
comments.author: mrule

comments.text: On second thought it seems like steel wire coat-hangers are probably more environmentally friendly -- most metals rust away faster than anything else can decompose, and its not clear that ABS used in 3D printing is really environmentally friendly, especially since we don't have good ways of recycling prints yet. PLA is 'Biodegradable' but will only degrade faster than normal plastic under special conditions, if I understand correctly. There are many problems to solve before 3D printing can be considered sustainable.
comments.author: mrule

comments.text: Wire hangers are really hard on the shoulders of blazers and suit jackets. This allows for a nice rounded shoulder while using a minimum of "new" plastic and reusing existing plastic for the bulk of the size. Plus, you don't have to jump in the car and waste gas to go to the store to buy a pack of jacket hangers.
comments.author: mrule

comments.text: You can use an extruder to respool your waste. Look up the filastruder you'll be happy I told you about it. I don't own a 3D printer quite yet but I'm getting one and an extruder to recycle my waste, and cut down on cost.
comments.author: mrule

comments.text: I would agree with you on the decomposition front - if there was a way to recycle the prints and/or use a material that biodegraded faster, that would be more friendly from a waste management perspective. It also would be more environmentally friendly from an energy-usage perspective if this wasn't a one off and was injection molded too. This design was intended more to highlight the ability to recycle the bottles that could have ended up in a landfill into something useful.
comments.author: mrule

comments.text: What a brilliant idea!!
comments.author: Rasle500

comments.text: This idea is amazingly clever! What a wonderful way to combine a 3D printer and recycling bottles to make a useful product. :)
comments.author: PolygonPusher

comments.text: Awesome! Its kind of funny looking, but its definitely a way to recycle 2 bottles for something useful!
comments.author: MiguelAlvarez

print_settings.Notes:: Really this is pretty easy to print; the settings you use just determine how it will look and how strong it will be when you're done. I use thicker walls to help prevent delamination, but that's me.
print_settings.Infill:: Infill is less important than the wall width; do that kinda thick-ish (I did 2mm)

description.text:
From the same people who brought you HamStudy.org, this is a customizable wall plate for anderson/powerpole connectors. You can make it handle as many as will fit on the single-gang plate.

For the retaining pin to hold the connectors in I use a 12AWG solid wire; usually a scrap of the copper ground wire from a romex 2+1. stick it through and then bend it at the top and bottom a bit and it works great.

IN ADDITION! This thing is crazy customizable; you can do a lot more with it if you play with it a bit. See some of the photos for examples.

Things to try:

  • Disable the screw holes by setting plate_screw_shank to 0
  • Make it all a flat plate by setting plate_depth and plate_thickness the same; optionally disable rounded corners by setting plate_corners to 0
  • Turn it into a panel mount powerpole block by:
    • setting the depth and thickness to 1 or 2
    • decreasing screw_distance
    • decreasing plate_width and plate_height to what you want
    • set plate_border to 0 (optional, but may help in some cases to let it be smaller)

Just about everything is customizable, allowing up to 3 boxes and whatever configuration in each of those boxes you want. I used it to create a wall plate to handle 2 3 pin connectors which I use for 24Vdc in my ham radio communications trailer, but you can do whatever you want with it.

This is licensed non-commercial. If you need a commercial license, contact me and we'll discuss terms.

I love this arm! The design is closely based on the original EMAX 250, and with a solid resin print, it weighs only 14 grams versus the 10 grams for the original carbon fiber. This arm does not require the use of a spacer :D
I left a handy access area where the arm connects to the quad's frame, so you won't need to unsolder your ESC wires when replacing a broken arm. The wires will fit straight through giving you a tidy assembly without fuss.

Although it was first created using a Form1, the part shown in the pictures was printed using a resolution of only 200 microns, so I don't see why it can't be made using many other printer types. Please let me know if you try it.

If using an UV curable resin...

If using an UV curable resin (e.g., Form1 printers), it is highly recommended that you paint the part to protect it from direct sunlight. Otherwise the part may become brittle and break.

Broken Arms

When you start flying more aggressively and taking chances at greater speeds, the crashes will become less forgivable. Even using carbon fiber, broken arms will happen. Why not experiment by printing your own? They are easy to make, easy to replace, and work great.

I designed this using a caliper to take measurements off of my existing, good arms. The thickness and the 2 independent outline ribs were adjusted for strength and weight.

title: Zonestar P802Q Y-Axis Motor Mount / Holder (incl. mirror)

description.text:
Printed mine in PETG, 0,3mm layer height, 25% honeycomb infill and fits very good and is very stable.

I've also uploaded a mirrored mesh version, as I wanted to flip the backplate of the printer, which increases it's usable priting space by a few cm without loosing precision.

I've also uploaded original construction files for Creo Elements (Freeware), if you want to improve it or you wan't to make it fit a different printer.

comments.text: That was a major screw-up on Zonestar's part where they placed the Y limit. I went a different route and made a plate to mount under the existing limit mount bracket, mounted the switch under that to actuate on the bearing under the plate instead of on the plate itself. Increased Y travel from 165 mm to 196 mm. I like your idea too. I guess you had to reverse the direction of the Y stepper in Marlin?
comments.author: Hart60

comments.text: I'd like to see a picture of what you did.. can you share one?
comments.author: Hart60

comments.text:
No I've simply flipped the cable polarity for the stepper instead of fighting with the firmware ;)
How to reverse the direction of a stepper is noted on one of the last pages in the original building manual.
Your method was the better idea, but at least I learned how to create 3D objects (this was my first object) ;)

description.text: Here is a replacement knob for a KitchenAid stand mixer. Came home to a broken one and of course no one knows how that happened. No biggie, just print one. The hole is slightly smaller than the diameter of the shaft because I heated the shaft with a heat gun and pressed it into place. When it cooled, it held well. I used PLA which melts at a lower temp. If you use ABS you may have to print it at 101% to allow for shrinkage. I printed the wall thickness at 4 layers to ensure it was tough enough to withstand that abuse.

print_settings.Notes:: We printed these supports with Innova, because we wanted them to last, but they are super easy to print so they will print will pretty much anything.

description.text:
This is an overhead filament spool holder made for a Lulzbot Taz 5. It will no doubt fit other printers.

We wanted a spool holder that was easy to use and eliminated the filament feed tubes that the original spool holder required. We print with all sorts of weird filaments that break easily, have rough surfaces, and generally cause the extruder to "grind" and stall. This spool holder eliminated 99% of the filament feed issues we were having.

The "on-top" design allows the filament to cascade directly to the extruder head with no friction. The center tube is a 3/4 inch (trade size) PVC tube, available in the hardware store. It has a very slick surface so it allows the filament spool to turn without resistance. The actual outer diameter of the tube is 1 1/16". I included a printable version of the center tube for those that wish to make their own from scratch.

You need two of the spool holders for each filament spool (one for each side, front and back) and you need 6 3/4" of 1 1/16" tube for the center. The spool holder just rests on the top rails of the printer and is held in position by the ridge the protrudes from the bottom that mates with the slot in the center of the printer rail. You change spools by simply slipping the tube out of one of the holders.

We have a dual extruder, so we have two pairs of holders shown in the photo.

If you like, you can secure the tube in one of the holders by threading a screw into the small hole in the top. You can also secure one of the holders (likely the rear one) to the printer rail with two screws and a pair of tee nuts or perhaps regular nuts wedged in the center slot in the printer rail. Seems to work fine for us just resting on the rails without screws, however.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

We printed these supports with Innova, because we wanted them to last, but they are super easy to print so they will print will pretty much anything.

comments.text:
Thank you so much!
May I know would it be a good idea to use the filament guide tube?
Like for materials like PLA and ABS v other fragile ones like PVA?
comments.author: KillaCycle

comments.text:
Since the filament hangs straight down from above, you really have no need of a guide tube.
We have printed with a large variety of filaments, and never had any issues with breakage.
The overhead spools feed the filament without the friction of the guide tube, which is the principle motivation for using the overhead spools.
